It would cut $1.35 billion in federal health care funding for our state by 2026 and even deeper cuts after that, imperiling our state’s hospitals, clinics, and health care workers—as well as the families who rely on them for needed care. It would raise premiums and out-of-pocket expenses for people on the individual market, making everyday medical expenses more unaffordable for New Mexico families. And it would strip protections for people with pre-existing conditions, meaning big insurance companies could go back to charging more for people who are sick – as much as $17,320 for pregnancy, $5,600 for diabetes and over $142,650 for certain cancers. We can’t go back to the days when millions of families are one serious illness away from financial ruin.   New Mexicans are fed up with their care being threatened and having to worry about whether they will be able to afford health insurance for their family. This latest attack is no better than the earlier versions of TrumpCare. Taking care away from millions is unacceptable. Republicans need to stop playing politics and start listening to the American people.  http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/national_and_world_news/senate-gop-musters-final-push-to-erase-obama-health-care/article_4cf057a4-449f-55ac-99dc-39869ac3593a.html

Senate Republicans are barreling forward with the cruelest and most devastating version of TrumpCare yet. This mean-spirited bill would strip health care from hundreds of thousands of New Mexicans like these and tens of millions of Americans by eviscerating Medicaid and causing premiums to soar.   The bill, which is even more radical than previous versions of TrumpCare, would punish people for being sick, and take away protections from people with pre-existing conditions. This is a blatantly political attack that will cause real hurt and suffering for people all across New Mexico and the United States, taking millions of families back to the days when they were one serious illness away from financial ruin. The chorus against this disastrous bill is loud and clear, from doctors, patient groups, seniors, and even Republican governors.    This bill would reap some of its worst damage here at home in New Mexico because of the damage it would do to the Medicaid program and the 900,000 people who depend on it. Graham-Cassidy would slash federal health care funding for New Mexico by a staggering $5 billion by 2026 – and the cuts only get worse after that, with New Mexico losing an estimated $60 billion over a 16-year period. These cuts would almost certainly force hospitals and clinics to close and leave families across our state with few options for care when they face an illness or need to see a doctor. The Graham-Cassidy TrumpCare bill brings us back to a time when the big insurance companies were allowed to charge New Mexicans more for being sick – as much as $17,320 for pregnancy, $5,600 for diabetes, and over $142,650 for certain forms of cancer. On the individual marketplace, over 33,000 New Mexicans would lose an average of $3,400 a year in support to help buy insurance.    What Senate Republicans are doing is truly unprecedented: trying to force through a bill to completely upend our health care system and one sixth of our economy without regular order, without debate, without a real analysis from the Congressional Budget Office. Senate Republicans even decided to kill productive bipartisan efforts to improve health care — all to try to jam through a partisan TrumpCare bill to dismantle all the progress we have made under the Affordable Care Act. President Trump and the Republicans are hoping that the American people aren't paying attention. I urge New Mexicans and Americans to show us all that they’re still watching, and that they'll never stop fighting to protect their care.

Senate Republicans are trying to force through the Graham-Cassidy repeal bill -- another version of TrumpCare that would be truly disastrous for American Indians and Alaska Natives. The bill’s massive cuts to the Medicaid program would devastate access to life-saving health care across Indian Country. The Graham-Cassidy TrumpCare legislation is an irresponsible and dangerous abdication of our federal government’s trust responsibilities to Tribes. If enacted, this bill would jeopardize the health and lives of Native Americans in Tribal and urban Indian communities everywhere.   This damaging bill would totally dismantle all of the advancements we’ve made to expand access to quality health services for American Indians and Alaska Natives. The Medicaid expansion under the Affordable Care Act has provided a lifeline to Indian Country, filling persistent funding gaps at the Indian Health Service and enabling IHS facilities to provide essential services beyond the ‘life and limb only‘ level.  Underfunding at IHS has forced Native health care facilities to ration care – and prior to the Affordable Care Act, people across Indian Country lived by the unofficial motto: "Don’t get sick after June." Now, thanks to the Medicaid expansion, many Native Americans finally have access to the services they need to keep themselves and their families healthy. But Graham-Cassidy would undo all that progress.     Republicans are clearly having trouble even selling this misguided bill to senators and governors in their own party. As vice chair of the Indian Affairs Committee, I’ve heard from too many Native Americans who are disturbed by the lack of Tribal consultation in the reckless Republican repeal effort – and who fear the devastating consequences of this TrumpCare approach to legislating. Instead of dismantling the gains we’ve made under the Affordable Care Act, we should be working in a bipartisan way to build on our progress, improve health care, and fully uphold our duties to Tribes. I encourage senators on both sides of the aisle to come together to oppose the Graham-Cassidy TrumpCare legislation and, instead, work to find solutions to ensure that everyone in Indian Country has access to the care they need.  https://www.cbpp.org/blog/like-prior-repeal-bills-cassidy-graham-puts-coverage-for-american-indians-alaska-natives-at

And our state’s economic future depends on ensuring that the next generation has the knowledge and skills – especially in science and math – to qualify for jobs in cutting-edge fields.    That is why Senator Martin Heinrich and I were so disturbed to learn that the New Mexico Public Education Department has proposed watering down science education standards for our public schools by removing any references to rising temperatures, climate change and evolution in our state’s K-12 science education curriculum. If we weaken our science standards to advance an ideological agenda at the expense of scientific facts, we will put New Mexico at a distinct disadvantage.   We urge all New Mexicans to make their voices heard as the Public Education Department seeks public input on their proposed new science standards. There is a better way forward that gives our students all of the knowledge and skills they will need to succeed. Read our op-ed here:   http://nmpolitics.net/index/2017/09/science-education-is-essential-to-nms-future/

Make no mistake, the Republican attacks on our health care aren’t over. As the vice chair of the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs, I will always fight to ensure Indian Country receives quality care, and will oppose any health care bill that fails to uphold Congress' moral and legal responsibility to Native Americans. Every radical version of TrumpCare we have seen so far would have been devastating for New Mexico and the nation. Today is a big victory for the American people, but we cannot become complacent. Hurricanes Irma and Maria have brought untold devastation and despair onto millions of American citizens in Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands—and their circumstances grows more dire by the day.  I am calling on President Trump to do everything in his power to provide much-needed relief and assistance to our fellow Americans, who are suffering immensely in the wake of these catastrophic storms.    Nearly all of Puerto Rico is still without power, and roughly 40 percent of people on the island lack access to drinkable water. This situation is dangerous, and it requires our immediate attention. The White House must act now to bring relief to the people imperiled by this disaster. The administration should mobilize air assets, the Army Corps, the Navy and Coast Guard to reach areas that have been cut off, help repair necessary infrastructure and deliver badly needed supplies.    Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands need all the support we can give them—and they need it right now.   https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/25/us/puerto-rico-maria-fema-disaster-.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=second-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news

Our democracy has reached a crisis point. The American people are losing faith in our electoral process and in our institutions – because they’ve seen too much evidence that our government no longer answers to ordinary citizens.    That’s why I’m introducing the #WeThePeople Act today with Congressman David Price. Our legislation will empower the people to take back our democracy and return it to the hands of all Americans—instead of a privileged, powerful few—by:  • Fixing our broken campaign finance system • Ending extreme partisan gerrymandering • Establishing automatic voter registration • Strengthening lobbying and revolving door laws • Increasing government transparency and accountability  It’s long past time that we took action to restore confidence and accountability in our democracy. Disastrous Supreme Court decisions have opened up the floodgates for secret, special interest money to drown out the voices of regular people. Foreign adversaries are interfering in our elections. Voting rights are under attack across the country. And big money donors are being rewarded with cabinet posts, high-ranking positions and special access. It’s time my colleagues on both sides of the aisle came together to return our democracy to the people. Share and spread the word—tell Congress to support our We The People Government Reform Act.

Today, the Senate Committee on Indian Affairs held a hearing on human trafficking in Native communities. As vice chairman of the committee, I will do everything in my power to ensure that Native victims of human trafficking get the support they need and to provide federal and tribal law enforcement agencies with enough resources to keep Indian Country safe.   But the federal government could be doing more now. Federal agencies should do all they can to collect and monitor data on human trafficking in Indian Country. And in doing so, they should be held accountable for working with Tribal governments and for making sure these data gathering efforts do not jeopardize victim confidentiality.  In the long term, individuals working in Indian Country – including Bureau of Indian Affairs law enforcement, Indian Health Service health care providers, and Indian gaming personnel – must receive proper training to spot, stop, and respond to human trafficking in the communities they serve.    We must work together to #EndTrafficking in Native communities. Watch today’s hearing to learn more about this growing issue and the ways we are working to combat it:    https://www.indian.senate.gov/hearing/oversight-hearing-gao-reports-human-trafficking-native-americans-united-states

Half of all school districts nationwide are allowed to punish kids when their parents haven’t paid their school lunch bill. Our children have enough to worry about—they should be able to focus on learning and growing, not being punished or going hungry for something they can’t control.   I’m proud that thanks to the leadership of New Mexico Appleseed and others, my home state of New Mexico is leading the way – it’s time for the whole nation to join us. Share this video if you think we should end #lunchshaming in America.

Jill and I join the entire nation in mourning the victims of the horrific mass shooting in Las Vegas last night, and we grieve for their families, friends, and loved ones.    One of the victims was a Lisa Romero, a secretary at Miyamura High School in Gallup, New Mexico. The students knew her as Ms. Lisa, and she was adored by everyone. I send my condolences and prayers to her family – as well as her school family – and to everyone in Gallup. Her loss will be deeply felt.  I also want to recognize the true bravery of our first responders – the police, firefighters, and EMTs – some of whom risked their own lives to save others. There are heroes in America, and we saw them in action last evening.  Nevada is a sister Western state. Many New Mexicans have family in Las Vegas, and we are reeling because of this tragedy. We must channel our pain into real action to honor the memories of those we have lost. New Mexicans looking for a way to help: consider donating blood. You can find a location near you in Albuquerque, Farmington, Rio Rancho or Santa Fe: https://bloodhero.com/index.cfm?group=page&pgfunction=fixedsitesnm  Congress also has the power to do something about this epidemic. It’s long past time we did. I hope we can come together to say enough is enough and focus resources and policy on preventing future senseless acts of gun violence.

I’m joining Senator Martin Heinrich on the Senate floor to remember the late Senator Pete Domenici and his lifetime of work for New Mexico. Whether he was fighting for our national labs and military bases or working to improve mental health care, Senator Domenici was a statesman who worked across party lines to find pragmatic solutions for the American people.  Senator Domenici and I didn’t always see eye to eye on policy—but I always appreciated that he cared deeply about the issues and did his best to put the nation and New Mexico’s interests first. I join all of New Mexico in thanking him for his contributions to our state and our country and in mourning his passing.

Today I joined Senator Richard Blumenthal, families from around the country, and experts to speak out against Michael Dourson, President Trump’s dangerous nominee to lead the EPA’s toxics bureau.   Throughout his career, Dourson has generated junk science to help protect corporate polluters and industry who want to downplay concerns about their products, including second-hand tobacco smoke and PFOA, the chemical in Teflon linked to cancer.    A toxicologist-for-hire has no business running the EPA’s toxics bureau. Share to help us spread the word and tell the Senate to #RejectDourson.

The BLM’s natural gas waste prevention rule prevents the waste of $100 million in taxpayer-owned natural gas every year, creates jobs in the growing field of methane capture technology, and helps reduce dangerous pollution across the West and in New Mexico, where a methane cloud the size of Delaware is hanging over the Four Corners region. So I’m deeply disappointed in the Trump administration’s proposal today, which would suspend or delay parts of this rule.   Tomorrow, the BLM will begin accepting comment on its proposal, and I encourage every New Mexican and every American to speak out against the Trump administration’s plan. The administration’s arguments for the proposal don’t hold water. Since the rule came into effect in November 2016, employment data shows no evidence of any jobs lost, and the number of drilling rigs in operation has increased significantly. Everyone should agree that preventing the waste of taxpayer-owned resources and protecting the air we breathe should not only be a goal – it’s our obligation. Many New Mexicans have spoken out -- including Rio Arriba rancher Don Schreiber, who visited me to help highlight how the BLM’s rule protects Western families like his from waste and pollution. Thanks to constituents like Don raising their voices, senators from both parties came together to save this common-sense rule in May. We can do it again.

WATCH LIVE: I’m joining a bipartisan group of congressional lawmakers to call for the permanent reauthorization and mandatory full funding of the Land and Water Conservation Fund (LWCF). The LWCF is a smart investment in conservation that costs taxpayers nothing and pays dividends. For every $1 invested, local communities see a $4 return. The LWCF helps sustain the $887 billion outdoor recreation economy—including 100,000 jobs in New Mexico  New Mexicans can thank the LWCF for creating and protecting urban parks like Valle de Oro and Petroglyph National Monument, for special places like Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rock National Monument and for conservation in the Gila, Cibola, Santa Fe and Carson national forests.  The LWCF will expire in 52 weeks unless Congress acts. Today, we're launching the #SaveLWCF campaign to ensure this vital program continues working for decades to come—for the economy, sportsmen, veterans, wildlife, and our kids and grandkids. Share and join the fight to #SaveLWCF!

The Trump administration’s continued denial of climate change in service of big polluters will have grave consequences for our children and our grandchildren. Killing the Clean Power Plan is a reckless and dangerous decision that jeopardizes the health, safety, economy, and way of life of people in New Mexico and across the country. Yet again, the Trump administration is turning its back on the public interest, and future generations will pay the price. Our political system is broken and the American people have lost faith in our democracy. A critical lack of transparency and accountability has left the door open for big money donors, foreign actors, and special interests to take advantage of our electoral and governing processes. As E.J. Dionne says in this column, reform “happens when even those who are skeptical of change realize that the existing system cannot sustain itself. If Trump’s rise and the abuses of his presidency do not persuade us about the depth of our problem, nothing will.”   President Trump has rewarded big money donors with cabinet posts and high ranking positions across our government—and, once in power, many of these officials are putting corporate bottom lines ahead of the health and wellbeing of American families, our environment, and our future. President Trump has refused to acknowledge or address the serious threat posed by foreign interference in our election. And he’s failed to divest from his conflicts of interest or disclose his tax returns or release his visitor logs, leaving the American people to wonder if he’s acting in their best interests, or his own.    I’ve been proud to lead the fight for campaign finance and electoral reform. We need to #GetMoneyOut of our elections, protect voting rights, close the revolving door in Washington and stop letting government officials use their power to enrich themselves. Let’s take back our democracy and return it to the hands of all Americans, instead of a privileged, powerful few.   Read and share this column on the #WeThePeople Act I introduced with Congressman David Price of North Carolina:  https://www.washingtonpost.com/amphtml/opinions/want-to-deepen-our-democracy-get-ready/2017/10/15/f0c2347a-b040-11e7-be94-fabb0f1e9ffb_story.html

Senate Republicans are hoping that the American people won’t notice their attempt to plunder this magnificent place. Watch and share my live floor speech and join me in speaking out against this terrible proposal.

ALERT: Republicans are waging an attack on our public lands in order to pay for tax cuts for the ultra-wealthy. I’m on the Senate floor standing up for families across New Mexico and America who rely on the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), home visits, our community health centers and the Special Diabetes Program for Indians (SPDI). It’s long past time that Republicans stopped playing politics with people’s health care and work with Democrats to fund these vital programs that help ensure families can get the health care they need to live and thrive.

Happy 100th birthday, New Mexico Museum of Art!   This weekend, I was honored to join the Museum of Art's centennial celebration. The City of Santa Fe and all of New Mexico are truly lucky to have this iconic museum — which, for 100 years, has exhibited New Mexico artists, brought in visitors from around the world, and advanced the arts in Santa Fe and across New Mexico. From Los Cinco Pintores in 1921, to Will Shuster’s courtyard murals in 1934, to the Santa Fe Chamber Musical Festival beginning in 1973, to its years devoted to showcasing Native American artists, the museum has empowered artists to inspire us, unite us, and speak the truth.     The enduring strength of the New Mexico Museum of Art is a testament to the critical role that the arts and artists play in our nation – and to the immense support that the arts enjoy among New Mexicans and the American people. The arts are an important economic driver, helping to diversify and strengthen our economy in New Mexico, where one in 10 New Mexico jobs is related to the arts or cultural tourism. At the federal, state, and local levels, we must do all we can to support development of the creative economy in our state. That’s why I continue to fight on the Senate Appropriations Committee to ensure that agencies like the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities have the resources they need to support the arts and artists in New Mexico and across the country. I’m glad to have worked with colleagues on both sides of the aisle to stave off President Trump’s disastrous proposal to eliminate these agencies, and to secure level funding for the NEH and NEA in the coming year.     In 1963, John Kennedy gave tribute to poet Robert Frost after his death. President Kennedy quoted Frost, who said, “If sometimes our great artists have been the most critical of our society, it is because their sensitivity and their concern for justice, which must motivate any true artist, makes him aware that our Nation falls short of its highest potential. I see little of more importance to the future of our country and our civilization than full recognition of the place of the artist.”  I agree. The mission of the New Mexico Museum of Art could not be more important in today’s world. Thank you Secretary Veronica Gonzales, Executive Director Mary Kershaw, and the entire museum staff for the important work you do for New Mexico. Here’s to the next 100 years!  http://krqe.com/2017/11/26/a-look-back-at-100-years-of-the-new-mexico-museum-of-art/

If you’re wondering just how bad the Republican tax bill would be for New Mexico, there’s some important reading in today’s The Santa Fe New Mexican (http://www.santafenewmexican.com/news/local_news/tax-reform-could-cost-millions-for-new-mexico/article_caa6f681-e796-5235-966e-800903c5ac40.html) and Albuquerque Journal (https://www.abqjournal.com/1099158/legislators-federal-tax-plan-could-devastate-nm.html). Republicans don’t want to talk about the fact that their tax bill will cost $1.4 trillion, and they don’t have the money to pay for it. The bill would also impose mandatory cuts to Medicare providers, and that combined with the provision that dismantles the Affordable Care Act would dramatically increase health care costs for the states. The bill also would  force mandatory cuts to farm payments, public safety, education, and a long list of other programs that supplement state funding and help meet the needs of taxpayers in New Mexico and across the country.   The bottom line is that this tax bill is a scam – a scam that would not only leave taxpayers with less money in their pockets, but also leave the state with fewer resources to meet critical needs. For example, CEOs would be able to write off corporate jets, but regular people could no longer deduct student loan interest. That’s outrageous.    I’ve heard from New Mexicans from across the state who are angry about this proposal, and I need you to keep making your voices heard so we can stop this terrible deal for New Mexico.

Washington Republicans have snuck plenty of dangerous provisions into the tax bill they’re trying to force through Congress. Here’s one you might have missed: a backdoor effort to allow millionaires and billionaires to make unlimited tax deductible donations to nonprofits – even churches and charities – that could be used in political campaigns. Thousands of religious organizations and faith leaders are raising the alarm about this misguided proposal to undermine campaign finance rules by politicizing nonprofit organizations.   For decades, a law known as the “Johnson Amendment” has protected religious organizations and nonprofits by requiring that these 501(c)(3) tax exempt organizations refrain from political activity. There are plenty of ways to voice your political views and get involved in elections, and nothing prevents a pastor from speaking his or her mind on Sunday about what is just and moral. But for over 60 years, the law has allowed charities, churches and other houses of worship to focus on serving the needs of worshipers and our communities without the distraction of politics – or worse, division over partisan disagreements. On Thursday, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) is expected to vote along party lines to roll back net neutrality rules, and the future of the open internet is at stake.   If the three Republicans on the FCC, led by Chairman Ajit Pai, succeed, internet service providers will be able block, slow, and throttle internet service to certain users, and charge websites and online services for faster and more reliable internet access. This will affect New Mexicans in many ways – from small business owners who rely on the internet to compete with bigger companies, to students who need to access internet content for school, to the growing number of consumers who stream television shows and movies instead of paying higher costs for cable.   As a member of the Commerce Committee and a champion for an open internet, I am urging the FCC commissioners to remember that their primary responsibility is protecting consumers and public interest, not reducing competition for big business. Allowing internet toll lanes is yet another example of President Trump and Republicans empowering big corporations at the expense of ordinary people. And not only would this plan hurt small businesses and consumers, it would prevent state and local governments from passing consumer protection laws for their own residents.  Too many New Mexicans, especially in rural areas, are already stuck in an internet slow lane. Instead of rolling back critical measures that protect internet openness, we should be finding ways to make affordable high-speed broadband accessible for everyone, no matter where you live.

I am excited to congratulate the 50 New Mexico students I have nominated to the United States service academies this year. A congressional, vice-presidential, or service-connected nomination is required for admission to the U.S. Military Academy (West Point), the U.S. Naval Academy, the U.S. Air Force Academy and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. Students who received my nomination completed a competitive application process, which included an interview with the military and community leaders who comprise my Military Academy Service Panels. The nominees will compete for admission to their service academy over the coming months, and those admitted will begin classes in the summer of 2018 as members of the class of 2022.
